Now let me again try to convince you that JUnit is only accepted 
today because of a powerty of Java language.

It is very simple.

If you try to correct yourself all the time as a developer then you 
will apply this principle to the question, whether JUnit and Test 
Driven Development (TDD) are really useful or whether they should be 
replaced by something better as soon as possible.

Using Design by Contract can completely make JUnit und TDD obsolete. 
Right now I'm not sure if it can make it obsolete for all appliances. 
But it can replace at least most usages of JUnit and TDD. And it can 
provide many more benefits than JUnit and TDD can offer.

Look at that example.

	/*
	 * precondition:  dividers[n] != 0
	 * postcondition: result[n] == denominator/dividers[n]
	 */
	int[] divide(int denominator, int[] dividers) {
	  int[] divisions = new int[dividers.length];
	  
	  for (int i = 0; i < dividers.length; i++) {
		int divider = dividers[i];
		divisions[i] = denominator / divider;
	  }
	  return divisions;
	}

Invariants would not be used here since invariants apply to the class 
and not to methods. They can be used for interactions or dependencies 
between methods.

It should be very easy to modify the java compiler to check whether 
the implementation obeys the preconditions and postconditions and 
invariants. If not, then either the implementation is buggy or the 
contract.

As an alternative you can use Design by Contract to automatically 
create test cases (including test data).

However you use Design by Contract: You save a lot of time compared 
to JUnit and TDD. And you aren't driven to use TDD. You are free. 
Besides this you have a very nice documentation (Contracts), much 
more helpful than the JUnit test "documentation".

Think about it.
